messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 63 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: The iteration time and the general position number in graph convexities

Paper Abstract: Abstract In this paper, we study two graph convexity parameters: iteration time and general position number. The iteration time was defined in 1981 in the geodesic convexity, but its computational complexity was so far open. The general position number was defined in the geodesic convexity and proved \NP\NP\NP-hard in 2018. We extend these parameters to any graph convexity and prove that the iteration number is \NP\NP\NP-hard in the P3subscriptùëÉ3P_{3} convexity. We use this result to prove that the iteration time is also \NP\NP\NP-hard in the geodesic convexity even in graphs with diameter two, a long standing open question. These results are also important since they are the last two missing \NP\NP\NP-hardness results regarding the ten most studied graph convexity parameters in the geodesic and P3subscriptùëÉ3P_{3} convexities. We also prove that the general position number of the monophonic convexity is W‚Äã[1]ùëädelimited-[]1W[1]-hard (parameterized by the size of the solution) and n1‚àíŒµsuperscriptùëõ1ùúÄn^{1-\varepsilon}-inapproximable in polynomial time for any Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0 unless ¬∂=\NP¬∂\NP\P=\NP, even in graphs with diameter two. Finally, we also obtain FPT results on the general position number in the P3subscriptùëÉ3P_{3} convexity and we prove that it is W‚Äã[1]ùëädelimited-[]1W[1]-hard (parameterized by the size of the solution).

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 63 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 63"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Characterization of general position sets and its applications to cographs and bipartite graphs",
        "The convexity of induced paths of order three and applications: Complexity aspects",
        "The convexity of induced paths of order three",
        "On the hull number of some graph classes",
        "On the carath√©odory number for the convexity of paths of order three",
        "Relating dissociation, independence, and matchings",
        "A partial k-arboretum of graphs with bounded treewidth",
        "On computing the dissociation number and the induced matching number of bipartite graphs",
        "Independent packings in structured graphs",
        "O N√∫mero de Helly na Convexidade Geod√©tica em Grafos",
        "On the convexity of paths of length two in undirected graphs",
        "The geodesic irredundant sets in graphs",
        "Characterization of classes of graphs with large general position number",
        "k-domination and k-independence in graphs: A survey",
        "Inapproximability results for graph convexity parameters",
        "The monadic second-order logic of graphs. i. recognizable sets of finite graphs",
        "Graph Structure and Monadic Second-Order Logic: A Language-Theoretic Approach",
        "Parameterized algorithms",
        "Inapproximability results and bounds for the helly and radon numbers of a graph",
        "On the geodetic iteration number of distance-hereditary graphs",
        "On the convexity number of graphs",
        "Algorithmic and structural aspects of the p3-radon number",
        "Parameterized Complexity",
        "Convexity in combinatorial structures",
        "Convex sets in graphs, II. Minimal path convexity",
        "Amusements in Mathematics",
        "Diameter and treewidth in minor-closed graph families",
        "The maximum independent union of cliques problem: complexity and exact approaches",
        "The hull number of a graph",
        "Convexity in graphs and hypergraphs",
        "Finding points in general position",
        "On the clique-width of some perfect graph classes",
        "Chordless paths through three vertices",
        "The geodetic number of a graph",
        "Convexity in graphs",
        "An improved approximation for maximum k-dependent set on bipartite graphs",
        "A perspective on abstract convexity: classifying alignments by varieties",
        "On the geodetic rank of a graph",
        "Reducibility among combinatorial problems",
        "A steiner general position problem in graph theory",
        "On general position sets in Cartesian products",
        "The general position number of integer lattices",
        "The general position problem and strong resolving graphs",
        "On the extremal combinatorics of the hamming space",
        "On no-three-in-line problem on mùëöm-dimensional torus",
        "Some results on graphs without long induced paths",
        "A general position problem in graph theory",
        "The graph theory general position problem on some interconnection networks",
        "The maximum time of 2-neighbor bootstrap percolation: Complexity results",
        "A note on the no-three-in-line problem on a torus",
        "On the geodetic iteration number of a graph in which geodesic and monophonic convexities are equivalent",
        "The complexity of dissociation set problems in graphs",
        "The complexity of restricted spanning tree problems",
        "Geodesic iteration number",
        "On the general position problem on Kneser graphs",
        "On the general position subset selection problem",
        "Complexity aspects of the computation of the rank of a graph",
        "The general position number of Cartesian products involving a factor with small diameter",
        "The general position number of the Cartesian product of two trees",
        "Parameterized algorithm for 3-path vertex cover",
        "Theory of convex structures, volume 50",
        "Node-deletion problems on bipartite graphs",
        "Linear degree extractors and the inapproximability of max clique and chromatic number"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 63 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in The iteration time and the general position number in graph convexities, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
